verses.text: He, therefore, who will not seek after that which is profitable to himself, is evil, to such an extent that his wickedness exceeds the very prince of impiety.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 44:9
verses.text: For he abuses the goodness of God to the purpose of his own wickedness, and pleases himself; but the other neglects the good things of his own salvation, that by his own destruction he may please the evil one".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:1
verses.text: Chapter LV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:2
verses.text: —Ten Commandments Corresponding to the Plagues of Egypt.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:3
verses.text: "On account of those, therefore, who by neglect of their own salvation please the evil one, and those who by study of their own profit seek to please the good One, ten things have been prescribed as a test to this present age, according to the number of the ten plagues which were brought upon Egypt.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:4
verses.text: For when Moses, according to the commandment of God, demanded of Pharaoh that he should let the people go, and in token of his heavenly commission showed signs, his rod being thrown upon the ground was turned into a serpent.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:5
verses.text: And when Pharaoh could not by these means be brought to consent, as having freedom of will, again the magicians seemed to do similar signs, by permission of God, that the purpose of the king might be proved from the freedom of his will, whether he would rather believe the signs wrought by Moses, who was sent by God, or those which the magicians rather seemed to work than actually wrought.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:6
verses.text: For truly he ought to have understood from their very name that they were not workers of truth, because they were not called messengers of God, but magicians, as the tradition also intimates.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:7
verses.text: Moreover, they seemed to maintain the contest up to a certain point, and afterwards they confessed of themselves, and yielded to their superior.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 45:8
verses.text: Therefore the last plague is inflicted, the destruction of the first-born, and then Moses is commanded to consecrate the people by the sprinkling of blood; and so, gifts being presented, with much entreaty he is asked to depart with the people.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:1
verses.text: Chapter LVI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:2
verses.text: —Simon Resisted Peter, as the Magicians Moses.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:3
verses.text: "In a similar transaction I see that I am even now engaged.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:4
verses.text: For as then, when Moses exhorted the king to believe God, the magicians opposed him by a pretended exhibition of similar signs, and so kept back the unbelievers from salvation; so also now, when I have come forth to teach all nations to believe in the true God, Simon the magician resists me, acting in opposition to me, as they also did in opposition to Moses; in order that whosoever they be from among the nations that do not use sound judgment, they may be made manifest; but that those may be saved who rightly distinguish signs from signs".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:5
verses.text: While Peter thus spoke, Niceta answered: "I beseech you that you would permit me to state whatever occurs to my mind".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 46:6
verses.text: Then Peter, being delighted with the eagerness of his disciples, said: "Speak what you will".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 47:1
verses.text: Chapter LVII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 47:2
verses.text: —Miracles of the Magicians.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 47:3
verses.text: Then said Niceta: "In what respect did the Egyptians sin in not believing Moses, since the magicians wrought like signs, even although they were done rather in appearance than in truth? For if I had been there then, should I not have thought, from the fact that the magicians did like things to those which Moses did, either that Moses was a magician, or that the magicians wrought their signs by divine commission? For I should not have thought it likely that the same things could be effected by magicians, even in appearance, which he who was sent by God performed.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 47:4
verses.text: And now, in what respect do they sin who believe Simon, since they see him do so great marvels? Or is it not marvellous to fly through the air, to be so mixed with fire as to become one body with it, to make statues walk, brazen dogs bark, and other such like things, which assuredly are sufficiently wonderful to those who know not how to distinguish? Yea, he has also been seen to make bread of stones.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 47:5
verses.text: But if he sins who believes those who do signs, how shall it appear that he also does not sin who has believed our Lord for His signs and works of power?".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:1
verses.text: Chapter LVIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:2
verses.text: —Truth Veiled with Love.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:3
verses.text: Then said Peter: "I take it well that you bring the truth to the rule, and do not suffer hindrances of faith to lurk in your soul.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:4
verses.text: For thus you can easily obtain the remedy.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:5
verses.text: Do you remember that I said, that the worst of all things is when any one neglects to learn what is for his good?" Niceta answered: "I remember".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:6
verses.text: Then Peter: "And again, that God has veiled His truth, that He may disclose it to those who faithfully follow Him?" "Neither," said Niceta, "have I forgotten this".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 48:7
verses.text: Then said Peter: "What think you then? That God has buried His truth deep in the earth, and has heaped mountains upon it, that it may be found by those only who are able to dig down into the depths? It is not so; but as He has surrounded the mountains and the earth with the expanse of heaven, so hath He veiled the truth with the curtain of His own love, that he alone may be able to reach it, who has first knocked at the gate of divine love.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:1
verses.text: Chapter LIX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:2
verses.text: —Good and Evil in Pairs.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:3
verses.text: "For, as I was beginning to say, God has appointed for this world certain pairs; and he who comes first of the pairs is of evil, he who comes second, of good.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:4
verses.text: And in this is given to every man an occasion of right judgment, whether he is simple or prudent.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:5
verses.text: For if he is simple, and believes him who comes first, though moved thereto by signs and prodigies, he must of necessity, for the same reason, believe him who comes second; for he will be persuaded by signs and prodigies, as he was before.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:6
verses.text: When he believes this second one, he will learn from him that he ought not to believe the first, who comes of evil; and so the error of the former is corrected by the emendation of the latter.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:7
verses.text: But if he will not receive the second, because he has believed the first, he will deservedly be condemned as unjust; for unjust it is, that when he believed the first on account of his signs, he will not believe the second, though he bring the same, or even greater signs.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:8
verses.text: But if he has not believed the first, it follows that he may be moved to believe the second.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:9
verses.text: For his mind has not become so completely inactive but that it may be roused by the redoubling of marvels.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:10
verses.text: But if he is prudent, he can make distinction of the signs.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:11
verses.text: And if indeed he has believed in the first, he will be moved to the second by the increase in the miracles, and by comparison he will apprehend which are better; although clear tests of miracles are recognised by all learned men, as we have shown in the regular order of our discussion.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 49:12
verses.text: But if any one, as being whole and not needing a physician, is not moved to the first, he will be drawn to the second by the very continuance of the thing, and will make a distinction of signs and marvels after this fashion;—he who is of the evil one, the signs that he works do good to no one; but those which the good man worketh are profitable to men".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:1
verses.text: Chapter LX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:2
verses.text: —Uselessness of Pretended Miracles.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:3
verses.text: "For tell me, I pray you, what is the use of showing statues walking, dogs of brass or stone barking, mountains dancing, of flying through the air, and such like things, which you say that Simon did? But those signs which are of the good One, are directed to the advantage of men, as are those which were done by our Lord, who gave sight to the blind and hearing to the deaf, raised up the feeble and the lame, drove away sicknesses and demons, raised the dead, and did other like things, as you see also that I do.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:4
verses.text: Those signs, therefore, which make for the benefit of men, and confer some good upon them, the wicked one cannot do, excepting only at the end of the world.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:5
verses.text: For then it shall be permitted him to mix up with his signs some good ones, as the expelling of demons or the healing of diseases; by this means going beyond his bounds, and being divided against himself, and fighting against himself, he shall be destroyed.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 50:6
verses.text: And therefore the Lord has foretold, that in the last times there shall be such temptation, that, if it be possible, the very elect shall be deceived; that is to say, that by the marks of signs being confused, even those must be disturbed who seem to be expert in discovering spirits and distinguishing miracles.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:1
verses.text: Chapter LXI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:2
verses.text: —Ten Pairs.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:3
verses.text: "The ten pairs of which we have spoken have therefore been assigned to this world from the beginning of time.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:4
verses.text: Cain and Abel were one pair.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:5
verses.text: The second was the giants and Noah; the third, Pharaoh and Abraham; the fourth, the Philistines and Isaac; the fifth, Esau and Jacob; the sixth, the magicians and Moses the lawgiver; the seventh, the tempter and the Son of man; the eighth, Simon and I, Peter; the ninth, all nations, and he who shall be sent to sow the word among the nations; the tenth, Antichrist and Christ.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:6
verses.text: Concerning these pairs we shall give you fuller information at another time".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 51:7
verses.text: When Peter spoke thus, Aquila said: "Truly there is need of constant teaching, that one may learn what is true about everything".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:1
verses.text: Chapter LXII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:2
verses.text: —The Christian Life.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:3
verses.text: But Peter said: "Who is he that is earnest toward instruction, and that studiously inquires into every particular, except him who loves his own soul to salvation, and renounces all the affairs of this world, that he may have leisure to attend to the word of God only? Such is he whom alone the true Prophet deems wise, even he who sells all that he has and buys the one true pearl, who understands what is the difference between temporal things and eternal, small and great, men and God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:4
verses.text: For he understands what is the eternal hope in presence of the true and good God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:5
verses.text: But who is he that loves God, save him who knows His wisdom? And how can any one obtain knowledge of God's wisdom, unless he be constant in hearing His word? Whence it comes, that he conceives a love for Him, and venerates Him with worthy honour, pouring out hymns and prayers to Him, and most pleasantly resting in these, accounteth it his greatest damage if at any time he speak or do aught else even for a moment of time; because, in reality, the soul which is filled with the love of God can neither look upon anything except what pertains to God, nor, by reason of love of Him, can be satisfied with meditating upon those things which it knows to be pleasing to Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:6
verses.text: But those who have not conceived affection for Him, nor bear His love lighted up in their mind, are as it were placed in darkness and cannot see light; and therefore, even before they begin to learn anything of God, they immediately faint as though worn out by labour; and filled with weariness, they are straightway hurried by their own peculiar habits to those words with which they are pleased.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 52:7
verses.text: For it is wearisome and annoying to such persons to hear anything about God; and that for the reason I have stated, because their mind has received no sweetness of divine love".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:2
verses.text: —A Deserter from Simon's Camp.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:3
verses.text: While Peter was thus speaking, the day dawned; and, behold, one of the disciples of Simon came, crying out: "I beseech thee, O Peter, receive me, a wretch, who have been deceived by Simon the magician, to whom I gave heed as to a heavenly God, by reason of those miracles which I saw him perform.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:4
verses.text: But when I heard your discourses, I began to think him a man, and indeed a wicked man; nevertheless, when he went out from this I alone followed him, for I had not yet clearly perceived his impieties.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:5
verses.text: But when he saw me following him, he called me blessed, and led me to his house; and about the middle of the night he said to me, 'I shall make you better than all men, if you will remain with me even till the end.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:6
verses.text: ' When I had promised him this, he demanded of me an oath of perseverance; and having got this, he placed upon my shoulders some of his polluted and accursed secret things, that I might carry them, and ordered me to follow him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:7
verses.text: But when we came to the sea, he went aboard a boat which happened to be there, and took from my neck what he had ordered me to carry.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:8
verses.text: And as he came out a little after, bringing nothing with him, he must have thrown it into the sea.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:9
verses.text: Then he asked me to go with him, saying that he was going to Rome, and that there he would please the people so much, that he should be reckoned a god, and publicly gifted with divine honours.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:10
verses.text: 'Then,' said he, 'if you wish to return hither, I shall send you back, loaded with all riches, and upheld by various services.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:11
verses.text: ' When I heard this, and saw nothing in him in accordance with this profession, but perceived that he was a magician and a deceiver, I answered: 'Pardon me, I pray you; for I have a pain in my feet, and therefore I am not able to leave Caesarea.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:12
verses.text: Besides, I have a wife and little children, whom I cannot leave by any means.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:13
verses.text: ' When he heard this, he charged me with sloth, and set out towards Dora, saying, 'You will be sorry, when you hear what glory I shall get in the city of Rome.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 53:14
verses.text: ' And after this he set out for Rome, as he said; but I hastily returned hither, entreating you to receive me to penitence, because I have been deceived by him".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:2
verses.text: —Declaration of Simon's Wickedness.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:3
verses.text: When he who had returned from Simon had thus spoken, Peter ordered him to sit down in the court.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:4
verses.text: And he himself going forth, and seeing immense crowds, far more than on the previous days, stood in his usual place; and pointing out him who had come, began to discourse as follows: "This man whom I point out to you, brethren, has just come to me, telling me of the wicked practices of Simon, and how he has thrown the implements of his wickedness into the sea, not induced to do so by repentance, but being afraid lest, being detected, he should be subjected to the public laws.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:5
verses.text: And he asked this man, as he tells me, to remain with him, promising him immense gifts; and when he could not persuade him to do so, he left him, reproaching him for sluggishness, and set out for Rome".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:6
verses.text: When Peter had intimated this to the crowd, the man himself who had returned from Simon stood up, and began to state to the people everything relating to Simon's crimes.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 54:7
verses.text: And when they were shocked by the things which they heard that Simon had done by his magical acts, Peter said:.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:1
verses.text: Chapter LXV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:2
verses.text: —Peter Resolves to Follow Simon.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:3
verses.text: "Be not, my brethren, distressed by those things that have been done, but give heed to the future: for what is passed is ended; but the things which threaten are dangerous to those who shall fall in with them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:4
verses.text: For offences shall never be wanting in this world, so long as the enemy is permitted to act according to his will; in order that the prudent and those who understood his wiles may be conquerors in the contests which he raises against them; but that those who neglect to learn the things that pertain to the salvation of their souls, may be taken by him with merited deceptions.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:5
verses.text: Since, therefore, as you have heard, Simon has gone forth to preoccupy the ears of the Gentiles who are called to salvation, it is necessary that I also follow upon his track, so that whatever disputations he raises may be corrected by us.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 55:6
verses.text: But inasmuch as it is right that greater anxiety should be felt concerning you who are already received within the walls of life,—for if that which has been actually acquired perish, a positive loss is sustained; while with respect to that which has not yet been acquired, if it can be got, there is so much gain; but if not, the only loss is that there is no gain;—in order, therefore, that you may be more and more confirmed in the truth, and the nations who are called to salvation may in no way be prevented by the wickedness of Simon, I have thought good to ordain Zacchaeus as pastor over you, and to remain with you myself for three months; and so to go to the Gentiles, lest through our delaying longer, and the crimes of Simon stalking in every direction, they should become incurable".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:2
verses.text: —Zacchaeus Made Bishop of Caesarea; Presbyters and Deacons Ordained.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:3
verses.text: At this announcement all the people wept, hearing that he was going to leave them; and Peter, sympathizing with them, himself also shed tears; and looking up to heaven, he said: "To Thee, O God, who hast made heaven and earth, and all things that are in them, we pour out the prayer of supplication, that Thou wouldest comfort those who have recourse to Thee in their tribulation.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:4
verses.text: For by reason of the affection that they have towards Thee, they do love me who have declared to them Thy truth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:5
verses.text: Wherefore guard them with the right hand of Thy compassion; for neither Zacchaeus nor any other man can be a sufficient guardian to them".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:6
verses.text: When he had said this, and more to the same effect, he laid his hands upon Zacchaeus, and prayed that he might blamelessly discharge the duty of his bishopric.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:7
verses.text: Then he ordained twelve presbyters and four deacons, and said: "I have ordained you this Zacchaeus as a bishop, knowing that he has the fear of God, and is expert in the Scriptures.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:8
verses.text: You ought therefore to honour him as holding the place of Christ, obeying him for your salvation, and knowing that whatever honour and whatever injury is done to him, redounds to Christ, and from Christ to God.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:9
verses.text: Hear him therefore with all attention, and receive from him the doctrine of the faith; and from the presbyters the monitions of life; and from the deacons the order of discipline.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 56:10
verses.text: Have a religious care of widows; vigorously assist orphans; take pity on the poor; teach the young modesty;—and in a word, sustain one another as circumstances shall demand; worship God, who created heaven and earth; believe in Christ; love one another; be compassionate to all; and fulfil charity not only in word, but in act and deed".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:2
verses.text: —Invitation to Baptism.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:3
verses.text: When he had given them these and such like precepts, he made proclamation to the people, saying: "Since I have resolved to stay three months with you, if any one desires it, let him be baptized; that, stripped of his former evils, he may for the future, in consequence of his own conduct, become heir of heavenly blessings, as a reward for his good actions.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:4
verses.text: Whosoever will, then, let him come to Zacchaeus and give his name to him, and let him hear from him the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:5
verses.text: Let him attend to frequent fastings, and approve himself in all things, that at the end of these three months he may be baptized on the day of the festival.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 57:6
verses.text: But every one of you shall be baptized in ever flowing waters, the name of the Trine Beatitude being invoked over him; he being first anointed with oil sanctified by prayer, that so at length, being consecrated by these things, he may attain a perception of holy things".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:2
verses.text: —Twelve Sent Before Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:3
verses.text: And when he had spoken at length on the subject of baptism, he dismissed the crowd, and betook himself to his usual place of abode; and there, while the twelve stood around him (viz.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:4
verses.text: Zacchaeus and Sophonias, Joseph and Michaeus, Eleazar and Phineas, Lazarus and Eliseus, I Clement and Nicodemus, Niceta and Aquila), he addressed us to the following effect: "Let us, my brethren, consider what is right; for it is our duty to bring some help to the nations, which are called to salvation.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:5
verses.text: You have yourselves heard that Simon has set out, wishing to anticipate our journey.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:6
verses.text: Him we should have followed step by step, that wheresoever he tries to subvert any, we might immediately confute him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:7
verses.text: But since it appears to me to be unjust to forsake those who have been already converted to God, and to bestow our care upon those who are still afar off, I think it right that I should remain three months with those in this city who have been turned to the faith, and should strengthen them; and yet that we should not neglect those who are still far off, lest haply, if they be long infected with the power of pernicious doctrine, it be more difficult to recover them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:8
verses.text: Therefore I wish (only, however, if you also think it right), that for Zacchaeus, whom we have now ordained bishop, Benjamin the son of Saba be substituted; and for Clement (whom I have resolved to have always by me, because, coming from the Gentiles, he has a great desire to hear the word of God) there be substituted Ananias the son of Safra; and for Niceta and Aquila, who have been but lately converted to the faith of Christ, Rubelus the brother of Zacchaeus, and Zacharias the builder.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 58:9
verses.text: I wish, therefore, to complete the number of twelve by substituting these four for the other four, that Simon may feel that I in them am always with him".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:2
verses.text: —Arrangements Approved by All the Brethren.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:3
verses.text: Having therefore separated me, Clement, and Niceta and Aquila, he said to those twelve: "I wish you the day after to-morrow to proceed to the Gentiles, and to follow in the footsteps of Simon, that you may inform me of all his proceedings.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:4
verses.text: You will also inquire diligently the sentiments of every one, and announce to them that I shall come to them without delay; and, in short, in all places instruct the Gentiles to expect my coming".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:5
verses.text: When he had spoken these things, and others to the same effect, he said: "You also, my brethren, if you have anything to say to these things, say on, lest haply it be not right which seems good to me alone".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 59:6
verses.text: Then all, with one voice applauding him, said: "We ask you rather to arrange everything according to your own judgment, and to order what seems good to yourself; for this we think to be the perfect work of piety, if we fulfil what you command".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:1
verses.text: Chapter LXX.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:2
verses.text: —Departure of the Twelve.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:3
verses.text: Therefore, on the day appointed, when they had ranged themselves before Peter, they said: "Do not think, O Peter, that it is a small grief to us that we are to be deprived of the privilege of hearing you for three months; but since it is good for us to do what you order, we shall most readily obey.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:4
verses.text: We shall always retain in our hearts the remembrance of your face; and so we set out actively, as you have commanded us".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:5
verses.text: Then he, having poured out a prayer to the Lord for them, dismissed them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:6
verses.text: And when those twelve who had been sent forward had gone, Peter entered, according to custom, and stood in the place of disputation.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:7
verses.text: And a multitude of people had come together, even a larger number than usual; and all with tears gazed upon him, by reason of what they had heard from him the day before, that he was about to go forth on account of Simon.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:8
verses.text: Then, seeing them weeping, he himself also was similarly affected, although he endeavoured to conceal and to restrain his tears.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 60:9
verses.text: But the trembling of his voice, and the interruption of his discourse, betrayed that he was distressed by similar emotion.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXI.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:2
verses.text: —Peter Prepares the Caesareans for His Departure.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:3
verses.text: However, rubbing his forehead with his hand, he said: "Be of good courage, my brethren, and comfort your sorrowful hearts by means of counsel, referring all things to God, whose will alone is to be fulfilled and to be preferred in all things.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:4
verses.text: For let us suppose for a moment, that by reason of the affection that we have towards you, we should act against His will, and remain with you, is He not able, by sending death upon me, to appoint to me a longer separation from you? And therefore it is better for us to carry out this shorter separation with His will, as those to whom it is prescribed to obey God in all things.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:5
verses.text: Hence you also ought to obey Him with like submission, inasmuch as you love me from no other reason than on account of your love of Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:6
verses.text: As friends of God, therefore, acquiesce in His will; but also judge yourselves what is right.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:7
verses.text: Would it not have seemed wicked, if, when Simon was deceiving you, I had been detained by the brethren in Jerusalem, and had not come to you, and that although you had Zacchaeus among you, a good and eloquent man? So now also consider that it would be wicked, if, when Simon has gone forth to assail the Gentiles, who are wholly without a defender, I should be detained by you, and should not follow him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 61:8
verses.text: Wherefore let us see to it, that we do not, by an unreasonable affection, accomplish the will of the wicked one".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:2
verses.text: —More Than Ten Thousand Baptized.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:3
verses.text: "Meantime I shall remain with you three months, as I promised.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:4
verses.text: Be ye constant in hearing the word; and at the end of that time, if any are able and willing to follow us, they may do so, if duty will admit of it.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:5
verses.text: And when I say if duty will admit I mean that no one by his departure must sadden any one who ought not to be saddened, as by leaving parents who ought not to be left, or a faithful wife, or any other person to whom he is bound to afford comfort for God's sake".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 62:6
verses.text: Meantime, disputing and teaching day by day, he filled up the time appointed with the labour of teaching; and when the festival day arrived, upwards of ten thousand were baptized.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIII.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:2
verses.text: —Tidings of Simon.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:3
verses.text: But in those days a letter was received from the brethren who had gone before, in which were detailed the crimes of Simon, how going from city to city he was deceiving multitudes, and everywhere maligning Peter, so that, when he should come, no one might afford him a hearing.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:4
verses.text: For he asserted that Peter was a magician, a godless man, injurious, cunning, ignorant, and professing impossible things.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:5
verses.text: "For," says he, "he asserts that the dead shall rise again, which is impossible.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:6
verses.text: But if any one attempts to confute him, he is cut off by secret snares by him, through means of his attendants.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:7
verses.text: Wherefore, I also," says he, "when I had vanquished him and triumphed over him, fled for fear of his snares, lest he should destroy me by incantations, or compass my death by plots".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 63:8
verses.text: They intimated also that he mainly stayed at Tripolis.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:2
verses.text: —Farewell to Caesarea.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:3
verses.text: Peter therefore ordered the letter to be read to the people; and after the reading of it, he addressed them and gave them full instructions about everything, but especially that they should obey Zacchaeus, whom he had ordained bishop over them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:4
verses.text: Also he commended the presbyters and the deacons to the people, and not less the people to them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:5
verses.text: And then, announcing that he should spend the winter at Tripolis, he said: "I commend you to the grace of God, being about to depart to-morrow, with God's will.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:6
verses.text: But during the whole three months which he spent at Caesarea, for the sake of instruction, whatever he discoursed of in the presence of the people in the day-time, he explained more fully and perfectly in the night, in private to us, as more faithful and completely approved by him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 64:7
verses.text: And at the same time he commanded me, because he understood that I carefully stored in my memory what I heard, to commit to writing whatever seemed worthy of record, and to send it to you, my lord James, as also I did, in obedience to his command".

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXV.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:2
verses.text: —Contents of Clement's Despatches to James.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:3
verses.text: The first book, therefore, of those that I formerly sent to you, contains an account of the true Prophet, and of the peculiarity of the understanding of the law, according to what the tradition of Moses teacheth.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:4
verses.text: The second contains an account of the beginning, and whether there be one beginning or many, and that the law of the Hebrews knows what immensity is.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:5
verses.text: The third, concerning God, and those things that have been ordained by Him.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:6
verses.text: The fourth, that though there are many that are called gods, there is but one true God, according to the testimonies of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:7
verses.text: The fifth, that there are two heavens, one of which is that visible firmament which shall pass away, but the other is eternal and invisible.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:8
verses.text: The sixth, concerning good and evil; and that all things are subjected to good by the Father; and why, and how, and whence evil is, and that it co-operates with good, but not with a good purpose; and what are the signs of good, and what those of evil; and what is the difference between duality and conjunction.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:9
verses.text: The seventh, what are the things which the twelve apostles treated of in the presence of the people in the temple.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:10
verses.text: The eighth, concerning the words of the Lord which seem to be contradictory, but are not; and what is the explanation of them.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:11
verses.text: The ninth, that the law which has been given by God is righteous and perfect, and that it alone can make pure.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:12
verses.text: The tenth, concerning the carnal birth of men, and concerning the generation which is by baptism; and what is the succession of carnal seed in man; and what is the account of his soul, and how the freedom of the will is in it, which, seeing it is not unbegotten, but made, could not be immoveable from good.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:13
verses.text: Concerning these several subjects, therefore, whatever Peter discoursed at Caesarea, according to his command, as I have said, I have sent you written in ten volumes.

verses.name: Recognitions of Clement Book III 65:14
verses.text: But on the next day, as had been determined, we set out from Caesarea with some faithful men, who had resolved to accompany Peter.
